metadata.title: Widgets | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Comprehensive Apple Human Interface Guidelines for designing widgets across all Apple platforms. Covers widget sizes, appearances, rendering modes, typography, color usage, interactivity, and platform-specific considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, watchOS, visionOS, and CarPlay.

overview.definition: A widget provides quick access to essential information and focused interactions from your app or game in additional contexts.
overview.purpose: Widgets help people organize and personalize their devices by displaying timely, glanceable content and offering specific functionality.

systemFamily.description: System family widgets offer a broad range of sizes and may include one or more interactive elements.

accessoryFamily.description: Accessory widgets display a very limited amount of information because of their size.

inline.notes: Inline accessory widgets offer only one tap target.

appearances.description: A widget can appear in full-color, in monochrome with a tint color, or in a clear, translucent style. Depending on the location, device, and a person's customization, the system may apply a tinted or clear appearance to the widget and its included full-color images, symbols, and glyphs.

fullColor.description: Widgets display in full color with original design intact.

light.description: Light appearance for widgets on iPhone/iPad Home Screen.
light.recommendation: Prefer light backgrounds for the light appearance.

dark.description: Dark appearance for widgets on iPhone/iPad Home Screen.
dark.recommendation: Prefer dark backgrounds for the dark appearance.

clear.description: The system desaturates the widget and adds translucency, highlights, and the Liquid Glass material.

tinted.description: The system desaturates the widget and its content, then applies a person's selected tint color.

monochromatic.description: Widget appears without color, used on Lock Screens.

standByLowLight.description: When the ambient light falls below a threshold, the system renders the widget with a monochromatic red tint.

iPhoneHomeScreen.description: People choose from different appearances for widgets.

visionOS.description: Widget appears as a 3D object, surrounded by a frame. It takes on a full-color appearance with a glass- or paper-like coating layer that responds to lighting conditions. People can choose a tinted appearance from system-provided color palettes.

iPadLockScreen.description: Widget takes on a monochromatic appearance without a tint color.

fullColor.description: The system uses the full color rendering mode for system family widgets across all platforms to display your widget in full color. It doesn't change the color of your views.

accented.description: The system removes the background and replaces it with a tinted color effect for a tinted appearance and a Liquid Glass background for a clear appearance. Additionally, it divides the widget's views into an accent group and a primary group, and then applies a solid color to each group.

colorBehavior.iPhoneiPadMac: System tints primary and accented content white.
colorBehavior.AppleWatch: System tints primary content white and accented content in the color of the watch face.

vibrant.description: It desaturates text, images, and gauges, and creates a vibrant effect by coloring your content appropriately for the Lock Screen background or a macOS desktop. People can customize the Lock Screen with a tint color, and the system applies a red tint for widgets on iPhone in StandBy in low-light conditions.

implementation.opacityBehavior: The opacity of pixels within an image determines the strength of the blurred background material effect. Fully transparent pixels let the background material pass through as is.
implementation.brightnessBehavior: The brightness of pixels determines how vibrant they appear on the Lock Screen. Brighter gray values provide more contrast, and darker values provide less contrast.
assetOptimization: Render content like images, numbers, and text at full opacity
Use white or light gray for the most prominent content
Use darker grayscale values for secondary elements to establish hierarchy
Confirm that image content has sufficient contrast in grayscale
Use opaque grayscale values, rather than opacities of white, to achieve the best vibrant material effect

contentDesign.guideline: Choose simple ideas that relate to your app's main purpose
contentDesign.details: Include timely content and relevant functionality. For example, Weather widgets prioritize current high and low temperatures and weather conditions.

contentDesign.guideline: Aim to create a widget that gives people quick access to the content they want
contentDesign.details: Display meaningful content and offer useful actions and deep links to key areas of your app. Replicating an app icon offers little additional value.

contentDesign.guideline: Prefer dynamic information that changes throughout the day
contentDesign.details: If a widget's content never appears to change, people may not keep it in a prominent position.

contentDesign.guideline: Look for opportunities to surprise and delight
contentDesign.details: Design unique visual treatments for meaningful occasions like birthdays or holidays.

contentDesign.guideline: Offer widgets in multiple sizes when doing so adds value
contentDesign.details: Small widgets typically show a single piece of information while larger sizes support additional layers of information and actions. Avoid expanding a smaller widget's content to simply fill a larger area.
Sparse layouts can make the widget seem unnecessary, while overly dense layouts are less glanceable. Create a layout that provides essential information at a glance.

contentDesign.guideline: Display only the information that's directly related to the widget's main purpose
contentDesign.details: In larger widgets, you can display more data but don't lose sight of the widget's primary purpose.

brandingGuidelines.details: Incorporate brand colors, typefaces, and stylized glyphs to make your widget recognizable but don't overpower useful information.
If your widget benefits from including a small logo, a small logo in the top-right corner is sufficient.

configurationGuidelines.guideline: Choose between automatically displaying content and letting people customize displayed information
configurationGuidelines.details: Some widgets need configuration (like Stocks), while others automatically display recent content (like Podcasts).
configurationGuidelines.developerGuidance: See Making a configurable widget documentation.

configurationGuidelines.guideline: Avoid mirroring your widget's appearance within your app
configurationGuidelines.details: Including an element in your app that looks like your widget but doesn't behave like it can confuse people.

configurationGuidelines.guideline: Let people know when authentication adds value
configurationGuidelines.details: If your widget provides additional functionality when signed in, include a message like 'Sign in to view reservations' when people are signed out.

updatingWidgetContent.overview: Widgets periodically refresh their information but don't support continuous, real-time updates, and the system may adjust the limits for updates depending on various factors.

guidelines.guideline: Keep your widget up to date
guidelines.details: Finding the appropriate update frequency depends on knowing how often the data changes and estimating when people need to see new data.
If people are likely to check your widget more frequently than you can update it, consider displaying text that describes when the data was last updated.

guidelines.guideline: Use system functionality to refresh dates and times
guidelines.details: Because widget update frequency is limited, let the system automatically refresh date and time information to preserve update opportunities.

guidelines.guideline: Use animated transitions to bring attention to data updates
guidelines.details: Many SwiftUI views animate content updates by default. Use standard and custom animations with a duration of up to two seconds.

updatingWidgetContent.developerGuidance: See Keeping a widget up to date and Animating data updates in widgets and Live Activities.

interactivity.overview: People tap or click a widget to launch its corresponding app. It can also include buttons and toggles to offer additional functionality without launching the app.

guidelines.guideline: Offer simple, relevant functionality and reserve complexity for your app
guidelines.details: Useful widgets offer an easy way to complete a task or action that's directly related to its content.

guidelines.guideline: Ensure that a widget interaction opens your app at the right location
guidelines.details: Deep link to details and actions that directly relate to the widget's content. Don't make people navigate to the relevant area in the app.

guidelines.guideline: Offer interactivity while remaining glanceable and uncluttered
guidelines.details: Avoid creating app-like layouts in your widgets. Pay attention to the size of targets and make sure people can tap or click them with confidence without accidentally performing unintended interactions.

example.functionality: Includes toggles to mark a task as completed

marginsAndPadding.overview: Widgets scale to adapt to the screen sizes of different devices and onscreen areas. Supply content at appropriate sizes to make sure that your widget looks great on every device.

default.description: Standard margin width for most widgets to avoid crowding edges and creating a cluttered appearance.

tighter.description: For content groupings for graphics, buttons, or background shapes.

platformSpecificMargins.mac: Widgets use smaller margins on the desktop on Mac.
platformSpecificMargins.lockScreen: Widgets use smaller margins on the Lock Screen, including in StandBy.

cornerRadius.guideline: Coordinate the corner radius of your content with the corner radius of the widget.
cornerRadius.implementation: Use a SwiftUI container to apply the correct corner radius.

scalingBehavior.iOS: The system ensures that your widget looks good on small devices by resizing the content you design for large devices.
scalingBehavior.iPadOS: The system renders your widget at a large size before scaling it down for display on the Home Screen.

marginsAndPadding.developerGuidance: Use padding(_:_:) modifier and SwiftUI for flexibility.

guidelines.guideline: Prefer using the system font, text styles, and SF Symbols
guidelines.details: Using the system font helps your widget look at home on any platform, while making it easier to display great-looking text in a variety of weights, styles, and sizes.

guidelines.guideline: Use SF Symbols to align and scale symbols with text
guidelines.details: SF Symbols work well with the system font.

If you use a custom font, do so sparingly, and be sure it's easy for people to read at a glance. It often works well to use a custom font for the large text in a widget and SF Pro for the smaller text.
In general, display text using fonts at 11 points or larger. Text in a font that's smaller than 11 points can be too hard for many people to read.
Always use text elements and styles to ensure that your text scales well and to allow VoiceOver to speak your content.

minimumFontSize.reason: Text smaller than 11 points can be too hard for many people to read.

dynamicType.implementation: Use Font to choose a system font or custom(_:size:) to choose a custom font.

principles.guideline: Use color to enhance a widget's appearance without competing with its content
principles.details: Beautiful colors draw the eye, but they're best when they don't prevent people from absorbing a widget's information at a glance.

principles.guideline: Convey meaning without relying on specific colors to represent information
principles.details: Widgets can appear monochromatic (with or without a custom tint color), and in watchOS, the system may invert colors. Use text and iconography in addition to color to express meaning.
When a person chooses a tinted or clear appearance, the system by default desaturates full-color images. Full-color images draw special attention which might make the widget feel out of place.

principles.guideline: Reserve full-color images for media content
principles.details: Such as album art for a music app's widget, and use full-color images with smaller dimensions than the size of the widget.
Prefer light backgrounds for light appearance and dark backgrounds for dark appearance. Consider using semantic system colors for text and backgrounds to let colors dynamically adapt.

accentedGroups.description: The accented rendering mode divides the widget's view hierarchy into an accent group and a primary group.

colorBehavior.iPhoneiPadMac: System tints primary and accented content white.
colorBehavior.AppleWatch: System tints primary content white and accented content in the color of the watch face.

vibrantModeContrast.guideline: Offer enough contrast to ensure legibility
vibrantModeContrast.implementation: Brighter gray values provide more contrast, darker values provide less contrast.

assetCatalog.note: In your asset catalog, you can specify the colors you want the system to use as it generates your widget's editing-mode user interface.

widgetGalleryPreview.guideline: Design a realistic preview to display in the widget gallery
widgetGalleryPreview.details: Highlighting your widget's capabilities helps people make an informed decision. You can display real data or realistic simulated data if real data takes too long to load.

placeholderContent.guideline: Design placeholder content that helps people recognize your widget
placeholderContent.details: An installed widget displays placeholder content while its data loads.
placeholderContent.implementation: Create an effective placeholder by combining static interface components with semi-opaque shapes that stand in for dynamic content.
examples: Use rectangles of different widths to suggest lines of text
Use circles or squares in place of glyphs and images

widgetDescription.details: The widget gallery displays descriptions that help people understand what each widget does.
format: Use approachable language and sentence-style capitalization
Avoid phrases like 'This widget shows...', 'Use this widget to...', or 'Add this widget'
examples: See the current weather conditions and forecast for a location
Keep track of your upcoming events and meetings

groupingWidgets.guideline: Group your widget's sizes together, and provide a single description
groupingWidgets.details: Group sizes together so people don't think each size is a different widget. Provide a single description regardless of how many sizes you offer.

addButtonColor.details: You can specify a color for the Add button that appears below the group of widgets you offer to help remind people of your brand.

lockScreen.description: Widgets on the Lock Screen are functionally similar to watch complications and follow design principles for Complications.
guidelines: Provide useful information, don't treat it only as a way to launch your app
A design for complications often works well for Lock Screen widgets and vice versa
Consider creating them in tandem with watchOS complications

alwaysOnDisplay.guideline: Support the Always-On display on iPhone
alwaysOnDisplay.details: Devices with the Always-On display render widgets on the Lock Screen with reduced luminance.
alwaysOnDisplay.implementation: Use levels of gray that provide enough contrast in the Always-On display, and make sure your content remains legible.

liveActivities.guideline: Offer Live Activities to show real-time updates
liveActivities.details: Widgets don't show real-time information. If your app allows people to track the progress of a task or event with frequent updates, consider offering Live Activities.
liveActivities.note: Widgets and Live Activities use the same underlying frameworks and share design similarities.

standByAndCarPlay.description: The system displays two small system family widgets side-by-side, scaled up so they fill the Lock Screen.
standByAndCarPlay.sharedBehavior: CarPlay and StandBy widgets both use the small system family widget with the background removed and scaled up to best fit the grid.
guidelines: Glanceable information and large text are especially important in CarPlay
Limit usage of rich images or color to convey meaning in StandBy
Make use of additional space by scaling up and rearranging text for viewing from a greater distance
Don't use background colors for your widget when it appears in StandBy to blend with the black background

lowLightConditions.description: The system renders widgets in a monochromatic look with a red tint.

standByAndCarPlay.developerGuidance: See Displaying the right widget background.

visionOS.overview: Widgets in visionOS are 3D objects that people place on a horizontal or vertical surface. When placed, the widget persists in that location even when Apple Vision Pro is turned off and back on.
properties: Size, mounting style, and treatment style impact perception

appearances.customizable: accented rendering mode with system-provided color palettes
appearances.frameWidth: People can customize the frame width of widgets using the elevated mounting style

designGuidelines.guideline: Adapt your design and content for the spatial experience
designGuidelines.details: Widgets don't float in isolation but are part of living rooms, kitchens, offices, etc. Consider this context early.

designGuidelines.guideline: Test across the full range of system color palettes and lighting conditions
designGuidelines.details: Make sure tone, contrast, and legibility remain consistent and intentional.

thresholds.description: Widgets can adapt based on a person's proximity with two key thresholds.

simplified.trigger: when a person views a widget at a distance
simplified.behavior: Display a simplified version with fewer details, larger type size, and remove interactive elements like buttons or toggles

default.trigger: when a person views it nearby
default.behavior: Show more details and use a smaller type size

thresholds.designGuideline: Maintain shared elements across both distance thresholds for smooth, continuous experience.

sizeGuidelines.guideline: Offer widget family sizes that fit a person's surroundings
sizeGuidelines.details: Widgets map to real-world dimensions and have permanent presence.

sizeGuidelines.guideline: Display content that remains legible from a range of distances
sizeGuidelines.details: People can scale a widget from 75 to 125 percent in size.
Clear hierarchy, strong typography, and scale. Include high-resolution assets that look good scaled up.

elevated.description: Widget appears elevated with subtle angle and soft shadow.
elevated.horizontalSurfaces: Widget gently tilts backward, improving readability and casting a soft shadow for grounding.
elevated.verticalSurfaces: Widget sits flush on the surface, similar to a picture frame.
elevated.idealFor: Content that you want to stand out and feel present, like reminders, media, or glanceable data.
elevated.customization: People can choose from different system-defined frame widths.

recessed.description: Content set back into the surface, creating a depth effect like a cutout.
recessed.idealFor: Immersive or ambient content, like weather or editorial content.
recessed.note: If you only support recessed style, people can't place the widget on a horizontal surface.

paper.description: Creates a more grounded, print-like style that feels solid and part of surroundings.
paper.lightingBehavior: Widgets become darker or lighter in response to lighting conditions.
paper.idealFor: Print-like look that feels like a real object in the room.
paper.example: Music poster widget displays albums and playlists like framed artwork.

glass.description: Creates a lighter, layered look that adds depth and visual separation between foreground and background.
glass.lightingBehavior: Foreground elements always stay bright and legible, don't dim or brighten with ambient light changes.
glass.example: News widget with editorial images in background and crisp headlines in foreground.

smartStack.backgroundGuideline: By default, widgets use a black background. Consider using a custom background color that provides additional meaning.
smartStack.example: Stocks app uses red for falling values and green for rising values.

relevance.guideline: Encourage the system to display or elevate the position of your watchOS widget in the Smart Stack.
relevance.details: Relevance can be location-based or specific to ongoing system actions like a workout.

dimensions.note: When Display Zoom is set to More Space
When Display Zoom is set to More Space
When Display Zoom is set to More Space
